description: Some unburned remains of uncertain origin, possibly a residue left after burning plastic, synthetic fibers or similar material.
Unburned remains of something that certainly was edible before it was burned; it's completely inedible now.  The cooking has gone very wrong for someone.
A handful of white powder with a sweet odor, also known as Chile saltpeter.  It can substitute for potassium nitrate for many uses, including making black gunpowder and food preservation.
White hygroscopic odorless powder, also known as magnesia.  It has a variety of niche uses in chemistry.
Pale yellow chunks of trinitrotoluene.  Best known as an explosive material with convenient handling properties, it is also used as a reagent in chemical synthesis to generate charge transfer salts.
White crystalline powder, also known as pentaerythritol tetranitrate.  It is a very powerful explosive material.
White granules of urea, also known as carbamide.  It can be used as a component of fertilizers, and can be used for making highly explosive urea nitrate.
White crystalline highly flammable powder, often used in improvised explosive devices due to the ease of acquiring the materials necessary to produce it.
Some bleach prepared for disinfecting water.  It leaves water safe to drink, but unpleasantly tasting unless boiled.  One unit is enough to disinfect two gallons of water.
A poisonous yellow-green gas that is extremely reactive and is a strong oxidizing agent.  Useful for chemistry.

A colorless, odorless and tasteless gas, vital for most living organisms, including humans.  It is an oxidizer, and its uses include include production of steel, welding and cutting of steels and other metals, rocket propellant, oxygen therapy, and life support systems.
A colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, and highly combustible gas.  Useful for chemistry projects and can be used as fuel.
A colorless and odorless gas that is a major component of air.
A common flammable liquid (or gas, at room temperature and atmospheric pressure).  In this form it can replace propane for grills and similar devices.
A white crystalline powder that tastes salty and smells of vinegar.  It has a wide range of uses in industry.  Also known as hot ice.

Chunks of lithium, a highly reactive soft silvery-white metal, that are stored in anhydrous mineral oil to prevent them from oxidizing in air during storage.  It's a main component of lithium-ion batteries.
//: Represented as liquid right now because of special storage conditions necessary.  Lithium would actually float in mineral oil, but there's no way to properly represent storing in inert gas at the moment.

description: A colorless gas with a sharp acidic odor in high concentrations.  It is a versatile industrial material.
White waxy, flammable, transparent solid with a strong aroma.  Camphor is used for its scent, as an embalming fluid, as topical medication, as a manufacturing chemical, and in religious ceremonies.

Toxic white crystals with a pleasant floral odor.  This compound is widely used as an industrial antioxidant, dye mordant and reagent and is also employed in agriculture as a fungicide and antihelmintic.

A semi-solid mixture of hydrocarbons, originally promoted as a topical ointment for its healing properties.  Its folkloric medicinal value as a ''cure-all'' has since been limited by better scientific understanding of appropriate and inappropriate uses.

A highly flammable chemical compound which looks similar to cotton wool.  One of its first major uses was a replacement for black powder as propellant in firearms.  Also known as cellulose nitrate, flash paper, flash cotton, guncotton, pyroxylin and flash string, depending on form.  It is currently submerged in water, in order to avoid an accidental explosion during storage.
//: Represented as liquid right now because of special storage conditions necessary.

description: A toxic colorless dense oily liquid with the odor of rotten fish.  It's used in rubber processing, herbicides and dyes, among other things.  Also known as phenylamine, aminobenzene and benzamine.
White crystalline powder which smells like geranium.  It is a widely used building block in organic chemistry.  Also known as phenyl ketone, diphenyl ketone, benzoylbenzene and benzoylphenyl.
A colorless, water-miscible organic liquid with low viscosity and ether-like odor.  Being polar and having a wide liquid range, it is a versatile solvent.  Also known as furanidin and oxolane.
White crystalline bitter-tasting powder.  Used as a reagent in chemical synthesis.  Also known as thiocarbamide.
White crystalline nonflammable hygroscopic powder with a sharp odor.  It is a powerful Lewis acid, and finds a wide variety of other applications in organic chemistry.
White crystalline nonflammable odorless powder.  Historically used for production of glass, soap, dishware, as a welding flux, and has many other uses.  Also known as pearl ash.

White crystalline powder with a characteristic odor.  It has uses in perfume as a fixative, and in pharmaceutical manufacture for the synthesis of antiallergenic agents and antihypertensive agents.  Also known as diphenylmethanol, diphenylcarbinol and hydroxydiphenylmethane.
White odorless nonflammable dense powder.  This chemical is used as fertilizer and is commercially known as nitrolime.

A colorless liquid with a sweet smell that can be detected at low levels.  It was formerly widely used in fire extinguishers, as a precursor to refrigerants and as a cleaning agent, but has since been phased out because of environmental and safety concerns, as it is also one of the most potent hepatotoxins.  Also known as tetrachloromethane, benzinoform, methane tetrachloride, methyl tetrachloride, perchloromethane, trematocide and many other names.

A colorless liquid with acrid odor, which is actually hydrogen bromide gas dissolved in water.  It is one of the strongest mineral acids known, and is mainly used for the production of inorganic bromides, especially the bromides of zinc, calcium, and sodium, as well as organobromide compounds.
Elemental bromine, a reddish-brown liquid with a bleach-like odor.  It is a strong oxidizing agent.

A colorless viscous liquid.  It is used industrially as a solvent and in the manufacture of some types of plastics, elastic fibers and polyurethanes, and is also used as a recreational drug.  Also known as 1,4-butanediol.

A colorless crystalline powder that is soluble in water.  It is a precursor for 1,4-butanediol and 2-butene-1,4-diol, used in manufacturing of certain herbicides, textile additives, corrosion inhibitors, plasticizers, synthetic resins, polyurethanes, and vitamin B6.  It is also used for brightening, preserving, and inhibiting nickel plating.  Also known as 1,4-butynediol.
A colorless poisonous, corrosive and flammable gas, with trace amounts in ambient atmosphere having a characteristic foul odor of rotten eggs.  It's mainly used as a precursor to elemental sulfur.
Dense gray water-insoluble powder.  It is primarily used to obtain hydrogen sulfide in laboratory conditions.

A colorless oily liquid with almond-like smell.  Being derived from lignocellulosic biomass such as wood, it is one of the oldest renewable chemicals aside from ethanol, acetic acid and sugar.  It is an important renewable, non-petroleum based, chemical feedstock.
Dense gray water-insoluble metallic powder.  Useful for chemistry and magnetic alloys production.
Dense red-orange metallic powder.  In this form it is useful for various chemistry projects.
Dense white metallic powder.  In this form it is useful for various chemistry projects.
White crystalline powder with a sweet earthy flavor.  Most widely encountered in food products as a preservative and a flavouring agent.  Also known as 2-furoic acid.
A colorless, flammable, highly volatile toxic liquid with a strong ethereal chloroform-like odor.  Used as a starting point for other speciality chemicals.

A light-gray powder composed of nickel and aluminum.  Used as a reagent and as a catalyst in organic chemistry, but needs activation with sodium hydroxide solution before use.  Also known as Raney nickel and spongy nickel.
A mix of cupric oxide and bismuth(III) oxide deposited on silica.  Used as a catalyst for Reppe synthesis in organic chemistry.
//: Needs a crafting recipe, but need more info on how it's made.

description: Brown-colored powder that is a mix of copper and silver oxide.  Intended to be used as a catalyst.
A brownish-red powder.  Commonly used as a pigment, a fungicide, and an antifouling agent for marine paints, and also is a semiconductor.
A colorless odorless powder.  It is a versatile precursor to many other silver compounds, such as those used in photography.  It was known as lunar caustic by the ancient alchemists.
A green crystalline powder.  Primarily used as an intermediate for producing potassium permanganate and shouldn't be confused with it, though it is an oxidizer on its own as well.

A purplish-bronze-gray crystalline powder.  Widely used in the chemical industry and laboratories as a strong oxidizing agent, and also as a medication for dermatitis, for cleaning wounds, and general disinfection.
A colorless powder.  This carboxylic acid is a useful building block in organic synthesis.
A colorless toxic and irritating powder with a characteristic odor.  It has been used as a herbicide, preservative and in the manufacturing of pharmaceuticals.
Black soft chunks of uncured rubber.  Usable for repairing car tires and some other light-duty uses.  It would be much more useful if shaped into an usable form and then vulcanized.

A colorless volatile flammable liquid with a pungent ether-like odor, almost exclusively used as a monomer for the production of neoprene, that is also known as polychloroprene.  This compound is also known as chlorobutadiene.
Dense white water-insoluble nonflammable powder.  Its main use is as a precursor to the fungicide copper oxychloride, and it is also a Lewis acid.
White water-soluble nonflammable powder.  Can be used as a fertilizer and as a flux in preparing metals to be tin coated, galvanized or soldered, among other things.
White nonflammable odorless powder.  It is a powerful oxidant, commonly used to initiate polymerizations.
White nonflammable odorless powder.  It is used as a disintegrating agent in analytical chemistry, as a precursor to prepare potassium persulfate, and to prepare potassium bitartrate for winemaking.

A colorless toxic liquid with a penetrating unpleasant odor.  It's used extensively as a chemical intermediate for products of various classes, like dyes and antimicrobial agents.  Also known as toluene trichloride and phenyl chloroform.
White waxy chunks of white phosphorus, immersed in water to prevent them from self-igniting in air.  It is highly flammable, pyrophoric and toxic, and known for its use in incendiary munitions.

A highly toxic colorless fuming liquid with an acrid unpleasant odor similar to hydrochloric acid.  It is an important industrial chemical, being used for the manufacture of phosphites and other organophosphorus compounds.  Also known as trichlorophosphane.

A toxic colorless liquid with a pungent irritating odor.  It is mainly useful for the production of peroxides but is generally useful in other areas such as in the preparation of dyes, perfumes, pharmaceuticals, and resins.  Also known as benzenecarbonyl chloride.

A white deliquescent powder with a rotten egg odor.  It's flammable, toxic and corrosive.  Its main uses are in cloth and paper manufacture as a makeup chemical for sulfur used in the kraft process, as a flotation agent in copper mining where it is used to activate oxide mineral species, and in the leather industry for the removal of hair from hides.
A toxic colorless flammable liquid with an almond-like odor.  It is a common solvent and a widely used intermediate in the manufacture of other chemicals.
A pale yellow powder with a sweet odor.  It is a common intermediate in the production of a number of industrially useful compounds, including common antioxidants found in rubber.

A toxic pale yellow powder with a mild aromatic odor.  It is used in the industrial production of pesticides, drugs, and dyestuffs, is a precursor to the widely used antimicrobial and bacteriocide chlorhexidine, and is used in the manufacture of pesticides.

A white crystalline irritant powder.  Primarily used to produce Nylon-6, and also as a reducing agent in many organic and inorganic reactions.  Also known as azinous acid, aminol, azanol, hydroxylazane, and nitrinous acid.
A toxic colorless flammable liquid with a sharp pungent odor.  It is as an intermediate in the production of herbicides in the chloroacetanilide family.  Also known as chloroacetic chloride.
An extremely toxic colorless oily liquid with a faint onion-like odor.  Best known as a reagent for the methylation of phenols, amines, and thiols.  Also known as dimethyl ester of sulfuric acid.

An toxic colorless oily liquid with a pungent irritating odor.  It reacts with water to form chloral hydrate, a sedative and hypnotic substance.  Also known as trichloroacetaldehyde and trichloroethanal.
A white odorless powder.  It is a reducing agent and its conjugate base is a chelating agent for metal cations.

A dense, colorless, oily, explosive, toxic and odorless liquid  with a sweet taste, dissolved in acetone to make it safe to store and transport.  It is a major component in the manufacture of explosives, namely dynamite, and double-based smokeless propellants, and has also been used in medicine as a potent vasodilator.  It will need to be poured into water before use, to separate acetone.
A white crystalline powder.  Found in urine and in kidney stones, it is used for the synthesis of caffeine and murexide.
A white deliquescent crystalline powder with a slight ammonia odor.  Primarily used to produce formamide via heating.

A colorless oily liquid with ammonia-like odor.  It is chemical feedstock for the manufacture of sulfa drugs and other pharmaceuticals, herbicides, pesticides and hydrocyanic acid, and has also been used as a softener for paper and fiber, and as a solvent for ionic compounds, resins and plasticizers.  Also known as methanamide and carbamaldehyde.

A white crystalline powder.  It is a purine base found in most human body tissues and fluids, as well as in other organisms.  Several stimulants are derived from it, including caffeine, theophylline, and theobromine.
Small chunks of brass.  Often used for making cartridge casings, non-sparking tools, low-friction mechanical parts and has many other applications.
A form of impure iron deposit that develops in bogs or swamps; looks like a brown rock.  Contains less iron than magnetite or hematite, but could still be refined into steel with a bloomery.
A handful of sand, rich with minerals eroded from a deposit.  Not as useful in this state, but might be a source of magnetite.
A chunk of hematite, an ore of iron.  It only needs to be smelted into usable form.
A large chunk of copper, in its native state.  It just needs to be worked into a more usable shape.
A large chunk of silver, in its native state.  It just needs to be worked into a more usable shape.
A large chunk of native gold, a rare find.  It just needs to be worked into a more usable shape.
A large chunk of native platinum, a rare find.  It just needs to be worked into a more usable shape.
A large chunk of native aluminum, which would have been priceless before other ways to obtain aluminum were discovered.  It needs to be cast into an ingot to use.
A large chunk of cassiterite, an ore of tin.  It just needs to be smelted into usable form.
A large chunk of galena, a lead ore.  It just needs to be smelted into usable form.
A large chunk of bismite, a bismuth ore.  It just needs to be smelted into usable form.
A large chunk of cinnabar, a red mineral from which elemental mercury can be obtained.
A large chunk of nickeline, a nickel ore.  It just needs to be smelted into a usable form.
A mixture of TNT and ammonium nitrate, for use in explosive devices.
//: Stats assume 50% ammonium nitrate and 50% TNT by weight.

description: A mixture of aluminum powder and ammonium nitrate, for use in explosive devices.
//: Stats assume 95% ammonium nitrate and 5% aluminum powder.

description: A white odorless powder. It is found in lithium-ion batteries and can be used as a treatment for mood disorders such as bipolar disorder.
A white odorless powder.  While classified as a strong base, it is the weakest known alkali metal hydroxide.

A blue-green crystalline odorless powder with a metallic taste.  Mainly used as a precursor to other iron compounds.  It is also a reducing agent, and can be taken as iron supplement to treat and prevent anemia caused by iron deficiency.  Also known as green vitriol, iron vitriol, ferrous vitriol, and copperas.
A blue powder, useful as a secondary explosive.  Also known as tetraaminecopper(II) nitrate.
//: REF unknown, assuming same as ANFO.

description: A colorless toxic powder which is a heat- and shock-sensitive primary explosive.  Useful for making detonators.  Also known as silver carbide.

A yellowish oily toxic flammable liquid with a pungent odor.  Most often used as a precursor to aniline, and also for masking unpleasant odors in shoe and floor polishes, leather dressings, paint solvents, and other materials.
A colorless flammable liquid.  Its odor contributes significantly to many of the varied, distinct, and unique odor profiles of marijuana.   Useful as a feedstock for some chemical processes.
A white crystalline powder with camphor-like smell.  Also known as bornyl chloride, endo-2-chlorobornane and 2-chlorocamphane.
//: Whether pinene hydrochloride actually is flammable is unknown right now; current assumption is that it is. Density needs to be confirmed as well.

description: A flammable white powder with camphor-like odor.  Used in the preparation of fragrances and as a food additive for flavoring.
A white crystalline powder with a pleasant pine-like odor.  Thanks to its smell it's used for making perfumes, among other things.
//: Melting point is 29 C, and that's probably why some sources refer to this compound as a liquid, but it is right now defined as a solid because in Cataclysm temperatures are lower than that much more often than not, whereas handling of frozen liquids is just inconvenient.  Eventually this should be taken into account in one way or another.

description: A white crystalline powder with a balsamic odor and a strong bitter taste.  Used as traditional anti-inflammatory medicine, for flavoring food and drink, adding scent to perfumes, and as an insect repellant.
A white crystalline powder with a pungent odor.  Also known as phenylsulfonic acid and besylic acid.  Can be used as a feedstock for phenol production.
